I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.    During the 2006 Country Programming Midterm Review Mission, the Government of the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  technical  assistance  (TA)  from  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  prepare  the  National  Strategy  for  Rural  Biomass  Renewable 
Energy Development. ADB included the proposed TA in the 2006 PRC operational program, 
and the concept paper for this TA was approved by the Vice President on 26 April 2006.    
 
2.   At the request of the Government, ADB fielded the Fact-Finding Mission in Beijing on 
19–28 April 2006, and held discussions with officials from the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA), 
which will be the Executing Agency, and the concerned ministries.1 During the discussions, the 
TA’s objective, outcomes, outputs and activities, implementation arrangements, cost estimates, 
and  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  were  confirmed.  The  TA  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.   Traditionally utilized biomass (e.g., either burned directly or in low-efficiency stoves) is 
still the dominant energy source in rural areas. In 2003, 50% of the rural population (about 400 
million  farmers)  still  relied  on  the  direct  combustion  of  wood  and  agricultural  residues  for 
cooking and heating. The use of these biomass fuels causes serious air pollution and health 
risks, and overexploitation of biomass resources has also caused significant environmental 
damage including erosion, deforestation, biodiversity reduction, and damage to watersheds.  
 
4.     Animal  wastes  from  rapidly  expanding  household  livestock  breeding  activities  and 
livestock farming regularly introduce massive quantities of non-point source pollutants to the 
waterways, contributing to deteriorating water quality. Based on estimates from ADB TA 3891-
PRC2 in 2001, the rural chemical oxygen demand load was 1.42 times the load from industry 
and urban sewage discharges. According to this study, by 2020 the rate of livestock production 
is expected to have increased by 167% from 2000 levels. A 40% reduction in rural nonpoint 
source pollution by 2020 will be needed just to stabilize pollution at its current high levels, and 
poses a considerable challenge to livestock producers. 
 
5.     Rural biomass renewable energy (BRE) is a sensible and cost-effective way to address 
both rural energy gaps and the rural non-point source pollution problem. BRE is created using 
animal wastes and crop residues, and is produced with solar energy (through photosynthesis), 
creating carbon-hydrates from carbon dioxide and water. BRE products used in the PRC include 
biogas, gases from straw and stalk gasification, electricity from biomass power generation, and 
various solid and liquid biofuels. BRE systems can be affordably established at both household 
and livestock farm scales, use readily available agricultural wastes, have few recurrent costs, 
need no highly specialized skills, and have high potential for extra revenues through Clean 
Development Mechanism (CDM) because of the potential for greenhouse gas reduction.

6.    Recent Government actions have strongly supported an enhanced national focus on 
BRE development. Rural BRE development is an important element in the Number 1 Policy 
Document Decision on New Socialism Countryside Development, promulgated by the Central 
Committee  of  the  Communist  Party  on  21  February  2006.  The  new  socialism  countryside 
development policy will promote (i) advanced farm production methods, (ii) improved livelihood, 
(iii) a civilized social atmosphere, (iv) clean and tidy villages, and (v) democratic management. 
The  first,  second,  and  fourth  areas  will  benefit  from  BRE  development.  Additionally,  the 
Renewable Energy Law, ratified by the National People’s Congress in 2005, has been effective 
since  January  2006.  This  law  supports  biomass  electricity  generation  by  requiring  the 
companies distributing electricity via the power grid to purchase biomass-generated electric 
power at a 0.25 yuan per kilowatt-hour premium. Finally, SEPA, as the national environmental 
administrative authority, is tightening wastewater treatment requirements for livestock farms, 
setting up strict discharge standards, and promulgating environmental management regulations. 
These policies range from command and control measures to economic incentives, but share a 
common goal of stimulating BRE development in rural areas.  
 
7.   The newly formulated National Renewable Energy Plan and Long-term Perspective (the 
Plan) highlights the importance of further BRE development. The Plan includes the following 
BRE development targets, to be achieved by 2020: (i) to have 80 million household biogas 
digesters in use (about 17 million now exist, with 63 million digesters to be constructed); (ii) 
increased electricity production through the development of 10,000 biogas power stations (there 
are currently about 700); (iii) construction of 15,000 straw and stalk gasifiers (there are currently 
about 520 gasification stations); and (iv) annual production of 5,000 tonnes of liquid biofuels. 
 
8.   There are substantial barriers to achieving these targets. These barriers include the 
affordability to the poor3, the economic incentives for the external investors to participate, and 
the absence of a cohesive and integrated national strategy. Particularly, the absence of a 
cohesive national strategy has led to further difficulties in developing rural BRE. First, there is a 
mismatch between resource supply and BRE demand. Following the release of the Decision on 
New Socialism Countryside Development and the approval of the 11th Five Year Plan (FYP), all 
provinces discussed their respective options for developing and using BRE. Biomass is not only 
used for energy purposes, however, but is also an important ecological material, serving as a 
fertilizer in rural areas. As BRE development increases, sustainability of this resource must be 
ensured, through attention to the carbon cycle, and to water, key nutrients, and biodiversity. 
Second,  there  is  a  risk  that  biogas  system  operations  will  fail.  The  lack  of  coordinated 
institutional arrangements results in different agencies promoting technologies through different 
financial sources. Insufficient technical support services and poor maintenance will shorten the 
life of a biogas system, and there is evidence that 50% of established biogas systems in some 
cities  have  stopped  operating.  Third,  large-scale  power  generators  have  limitations  under 
current situation. The Renewable Energy Law favors the establishment of large-scale BRE 
power generators, but without appropriate incentives for collection and transport of biomass 
resources by farmers, the radius within which collection of biomass resources is cost-effective 
will become a bottleneck for large-scale plant operation. Fourth, without sufficient guidance, 
local BRE development has been ineffective. An understanding of local resource availability, 
and the economic characteristics and diversity of BRE compared with other competing fuels, is 
required if BRE development is to be effective under local conditions. For example, biomass 
gasification technology needs to be developed with cost-effective tar removal systems. Biogas 
plants  should  recover  waste  heat  from  the  exhaust  of  engines  used  for  biogas  electricity 
                                                 
3 The subsidy program begun in 2003 remains an important incentive, but is not sufficient to make BRE systems 
affordable for many of the rural poor. Additionally, the existing productive capacity of poor farmers may be too 
limited to ensure effective use of a household biogas system.

3
generation.  Improving  the  operational  performance  of  biogas  plants  in  the  country’s  cold 
northern climate is a persistent problem. The utilization of digestion liquids as fertilizers and the 
promotion of eco-farming production through BRE development were also not well addressed in 
the existing regulatory framework. 
 
9.     Protecting environment and promoting clean energy is one of the strategic areas in the 
PRC  2006–2008  country  strategy  and  program  update4.  Since  early  2001,  ADB  and  the 
Government have been working together on rural BRE development through Loan 1924-PRC.5 
In response to the success of this pilot project, the Government requested (i) TA to develop a 
comprehensive strategy and implementation plan for rural BRE development, which can form 
the basis for discussions regarding a strategic partnership between ADB and the PRC on BRE 
development; and (ii) a specific investment to replicate and upscale the pilot project experience 
to other provinces, including consideration of medium- and large-scale biogas development.6 
This effort will benefit rural populations by improving living standards and addressing non-point 
source pollution.  
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.   The impact of the TA will be an improved rural environment, increased rural household 
income, and an ensured rural energy supply. The expected outcome will be promotion of the 
use of affordable, environmentally sound, and sustainable BRE through a set of policy and 
related implementation recommendations, covering institutional, financial and technical aspects, 
at the national, provincial, and local levels. 
   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.   The main outputs of the TA will be (i) a national strategy (short term and long term, 
covering  2006–2020)  for  BRE  development  in  the  PRC,  and  (ii)  a  partnership  framework 
between the Government and ADB on BRE development.   
 
12.   The TA will support the following interrelated activities.  
 
(i)  Preparation of a technical roadmap for BRE development on a regional basis, by: (a) 
dividing the country into appropriate regions, considering resource distribution features, 
economic  characteristics  and  BRE  diversity;  (b)  surveying  biomass  types,  resource 
availability, and distribution in the regions (including provinces, counties and villages); (c) 
evaluating the demand of biomass renewable energy in the regions; (d) surveying and 
selecting suitable BRE development technologies; (e) evaluating the constraints and 
opportunities for BRE development in the regions; (f) identifying the suitability of, and 
technology  pathways  needed  to  establish  a  roadmap  for  BRE  development  in  the

development needs of BRE technologies. 
(ii)  Development of an institutional and policy assessment for BRE development, by: (a) 
analyzing  the  policy  and  institutional  barriers  that  exist  to  BRE  development;  (b) 
recommending institutional arrangements, including coordination mechanisms for BRE 
development; (c) establishing incentive instruments to improve BRE affordability to poor 
farmers,  reduce  rural  nonpoint  source  pollution,  and  increase  public–private 
partnerships;  (d)  establishing  a  platform  for  information  exchange  between  all 
stakeholders involved in BRE development; and (e) providing international experiences 
to improve institutional capacity and inter-ministerial cooperation.  
(iii)  Preparation of an investment needs assessment and financing plan recommendations, 
by: (a) analyzing investment needs for achieving long-term BRE development objectives; 
(b)  advising  on  measures  to  improve  the  effectiveness  of  the  investment  program, 
including domestic bonds projects; (c) designing a financing plan, including domestic 
sources and external assistance; (d) designing strategies for attracting external financing 
(from lenders such as the World Bank and ADB, from bilateral funding agencies, and 
through private sector participation, and by investigating the applicability of CDM and 
Global  Environmental  Facility  (GEF),  covering  appropriate  financial  methods  and 
mechanisms and the possible integration of external sources with domestic bonds; (iv) 
formulating strategic options for rural BRE development; and (v) identifying where it is 
appropriate to utilize ADB assistance for rural BRE development.  
 
13.   Based on the TA findings, the TA will draft a national strategy with recommendations for 
short- and long-term BRE development strategic options, covering 2006–2020. The strategy will 
include recommendations regarding institutional arrangements, a technical roadmap, a set of 
economic instruments to increase affordability, measures for reducing rural nonpoint source 
pollution and promoting public–private partnerships, an investment program, and a financing 
plan. The executive summary will be submitted to the State Council for consideration.  
 
14.   The TA will prepare a partnership framework between the PRC and ADB on rural BRE 
development, which will be submitted to MOF and NDRC for consideration. The partnership 
framework will delineate how partnership with ADB can assist the PRC in implementing those 
aspects of the country’s New Socialism Countryside Development policy that relate to rural BRE 
promotion, and will address (i) where ADB assistance can be most effectively utilized; (ii) 
financial  approaches;  (iii)  assistance  mechanisms;  (iv)  coordination  and  cooperation  with 
domestic bonds, the World Bank, and bilateral aid agencies; and (v) cofinancing by GEF; and 
CDM applicability.  
 
15.   The TA will emphasize coordination and cooperation with concerned line ministries and 
stakeholders. A steering committee will be established, chaired by the vice minister of MOA and 
including senior officials of ministries concerned. An aid coordination mechanism will be formed 
for sharing information and exchanging experience.  
 
16.    Three  workshops  will  be  held  to  discuss  strategy  design,  solicit  comments  on  the 
roadmap and strategy, and reach consensus among key stakeholders. The first workshop will 
discuss the methodology and strategy development activities. The second workshop will discuss 
the draft strategy and partnership framework. The third workshop will assess the outcomes of 
the TA, and discuss the follow-up steps to continue partnerships after the TA is complete.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA cost is estimated at $600,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $400,000 on a grant 
basis through its TA funding program. The Government will finance the remaining $200,000 
equivalent. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
18.   This TA will closely coordinate with the ADB’s ongoing L1924-PRC Efficient Utilization of 
Agriculture Wastes Project and the project preparatory TA (2007) for the proposed lending on 
Rural Renewable Energy and Ecological Agriculture. All of the activities will provide a solid basis 
for TA implementation. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  The MOA will be the Executing Agency for the TA. A steering committee chaired by the 
vice minister of MOA will be established, comprising a senior official from NDRC, MOF, the 
Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST), SEPA and the State Council Leading Group Office 
of Poverty Alleviation and Development. The steering committee will provide overall guidance 
on the TA’s direction. The steering committee members will meet at and provide guidance 
through the three TA workshops.  
 
20.  A TA management office (TMO) will be established in the Rural Energy Division (RED) 
of MOA to carry out day-to-day TA operations. The RED director will serve as the head of the 
TMO and function as the overall TA coordinator. The Foreign Economic Cooperation Center, 
Rural  Energy  and  Environment  Institute  (REI)  and  RED  will  work  closely  and  be  jointly 
responsible for day-to-day communications and operational matters among ADB, consultants, 
and related government agencies.  
 
21.  A team of international and domestic consultants will be recruited on an individual basis. 
The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants. TA implementation will require 4.5 person-months of international and 40 person-
months  of  domestic  consulting  services.  The  international  consultants  will  comprise  (i)  an 
environmental and energy policy specialist (2.5 persons-months); and (ii) a biomass energy 
specialist (2.0 person-months). The two consultants should have extensive experience in the 
PRC, with knowledge of best practices in the development of BRE. The required expertise for 
domestic  consultants  includes  (i)  institutional  and  policy  specialist  (12  person-months),  (ii) 
biomass  resource  specialist  (6  person-months),  (iii)  biomass  energy  specialist  (6  person-
months), (iv) investment and financing specialist (6 person-months), (v) environmental specialist 
(5  person-months),  and  (vi)  social  development  specialist  (5  person-months).  One  of  the 
domestic consultants will serve as the team leader and one international consultant will serve as 
the deputy team leader. Outline terms of reference for the consulting services are provided in 
Appendix 3. Equipments to be provided under the TA will be procured in accordance with the 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. Implementation of the TA will take 18 months, from September 
2006 to March 2008.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.    The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the National Strategy for Rural 
Biomass Renewable Energy Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of international and domestic consultants will be recruited on an individual basis.  
The technical assistance (TA) will require 4.5 person-months of international and 40 person-
months  of  domestic  consulting  services.  The  international  consultants  will  comprise  (i) 
international environmental and energy policy specialist and deputy team leader (2.5 person-
months),  and  (ii)  international  biomass  energy  specialist  (2  person-months).  The  two 
consultants should have extensive experience in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), with 
knowledge of best practices in the development of biomass renewable energy (BRE). The 
required  expertise  for  domestic  consultants  includes  (i)  domestic  policy  and  institutional 
specialist/team leader (12 person-months), (ii) domestic biomass energy specialist (6 person-
months), (iii) domestic biomass resource specialist (6 person-months), (iv) domestic investment 
and financial specialist (6 person-months), (v) domestic environmental specialist (5 person-
months), (vi) domestic social development specialist (5 person-months). One of the domestic 
consultants will serve as team leader and one of the international consultants will serve as the 
deputy team leader. The international and domestic consultants will collaborate closely on TA 
implementation, and carry out the TA in response to the needs of the Executing Agency, the 
Ministry of Agriculture (MOA). A flexible approach will be adopted to allow each consultant to 
provide their services at the most opportune times, coordinated within the TA implementation 
period. 
 
A.   Tasks of International Consultants 
 
2.  Deputy  Team  Leader/Environmental  and  Energy  Policy  Specialist  (2.5  person-
months). The deputy team leader/environmental and energy policy specialist will work closely 
with the team leader to coordinate the work of the international and domestic consultants, and 
coordinate  with  the  Executing  Agency,  other  related  government  agencies,  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), and other international organizations. The deputy team leader will 
assist the team leader to periodically report the progress to the Executing Agency and ADB and 
submit high quality, consolidated reports to ADB as specified in the terms of reference. In 
addition to duties as deputy team leader, the following technical responsibilities will be carried 
out. 
 
(i)  Review  and  assess  international  experiences  in  rural  BRE  development  in 
developed and developing countries, and analyze their applicability to the PRC’s 
situation.  Prepare  a  report  on  international  experience  with  rural  BRE 
development and the implications for rural BRE development in the PRC. 
(ii)  Based on the results in (i), and inputs from the Executing Agency and other team 
members, design strategies for attracting external financing (from lenders such 
as  World  Bank  and  ADB,  from  bilateral  donors,  and  through  private  sector 
participation,  and  by  investigating  the  applicability  of  Clean  Development 
Mechanism  (CDM)  and  GEF,  covering  appropriate  financial  methods  and 
mechanisms  and  the  possible  integration  of  external  sources  with  domestic 
bonds.  
(iii)  Based on (i) and (ii) above and consultations with Government agencies, draft 
the partnership framework between the Government and ADB on rural BRE 
development. This framework will specify (a) ADB’s role in providing assistance; 
(b) the financial methods; (c) the assistance mechanism; (d) coordination and 
cooperation with domestic bonds, the World Bank, and bilateral aid agencies; (e) 
the potential for GEF cofinancing; and (f) CDM applicability.

roadmap for rural BRE development; (c) the draft national strategy for rural BRE 
development; and (d) the TA inception, medium-term and final reports. Revise 
chapters or sections if necessary to ensure that the TA outputs are adequate in 
scope and quality. 
(v)  Make presentations at the three national workshops. 
(vi)  Edit the final English reports. 
 
3.  International Biomass Energy Specialist (2 person-months). The consultant will do 
the following: 
 
(i)  Working  closely  with  other  consultants,  review  and  assess  international 
experience in rural BRE development, and the implications for the PRC. 
(ii)  Provide leadership and guidance in the design and implementation of a roadmap 
for BRE development. Assist in the survey and analysis of BRE resources and 
needs in rural areas. 
(iii)  Survey how current biomass energy conversion technologies are being used in 
rural  areas  (e.g.,  direct  combustion,  biogas  technology,  biomass  to  pellets, 
gasification,  and  biofuels).  Analyze  the  advantages  and  drawbacks  of  the 
technologies. 
(iv)  Assist the domestic biomass energy specialist to calculate and estimate the 
conversion efficiency and cost of various technologies. Address the readiness of 
the technologies for the commercialization. 
(v)  Identify  future  research  and  development  needs  relating  to  BRE  conversion 
technologies. Provide recommendations regarding priority technologies, based 
on conditions in rural areas. 
(vi)  Prepare  a  report  on  a  technical  roadmap  for  rural  BRE  development,  and 
conduct other related work as assigned by the team leader. 
(vii)  Make presentations at the three national workshops.  
 
B.   Tasks of Domestic Consultants 
 
4.  Team  Leader/Policy  and  Institutional  Specialist  (12  person-months).  The  team 
leader/domestic  policy  and  institutional  specialist  will  have  overall  substantive  and 
administrative responsibility for the effective and timely implementation of the TA. The team 
leader will foster close coordination between international and domestic consultants (including 
coordination of inputs, quality control of reports, financial management and technical guidance), 
and  coordinate  with  the  Executing  Agency,  other  related  government  agencies,  ADB,  and 
international organizations undertaking related work in partnership with ADB. The team leader 
will periodically report progress to the Executing Agency and ADB and submit high-quality, 
consolidated reports to ADB as specified in the terms of reference. In addition to duties as team 
leader, the following technical responsibilities will be carried out. 
 
(i)  Assist the international consultants to identify the needs of the Executing Agency 
in terms of learning from international experiences with BRE development, and 
review  and  comment  on  reports  prepared  by  international  consultants  on 
international experiences and their implications for the PRC. 
(ii)  Working with the Executing Agency and other consultants, analyze and evaluate 
how  the  sustainable  utilization  of  biomass  resources  (especially  agricultural 
residues) can be closely integrated with planning activities for food production,

rural development and energy supply. Study integrated planning practices to 
support the effective long-term management of local biomass resources. 
(iii)  Identify key barriers to rural BRE development (including affordability, policies, 
legislative aspects, institutional capacity and financial arrangements) that need to 
be addressed and considered in formulating the national strategy and institutional 
coordination mechanism. 
(iv)  Based on the analysis in (i) to (iii), and inputs from the Executing Agency and 
other  team  members,  prepare  a  comprehensive  national  strategy  report

and options for rural BRE development. The report should: (a) review existing

practices needed for BRE development; (c) establish incentive instruments to

pollution, and increase public–private partnerships; (d) advise on measures to 
improve the effectiveness of the investment program, including domestic bonds 
projects; (e) develop overall short-, medium-, and long-term goals/targets for

structure  of  domestic  sources  and  external  assistance;  and  (g)  include  an 
appropriate, timely, and cost effective monitoring and evaluation methodology for 
implementing the strategy and national action plan. 
(v)  At the end of TA implementation, help the Executing Agency draft a national 
strategy paper to be submitted to the State Council recommending further policy 
and institutional changes needed for effective rural BRE development. 
(vi)  Work with the international environmental and energy policy specialist and the 
domestic investment and financial specialist to finalize the Chinese version of 
strategic partnership framework for the Government with the ADB on rural BRE 
development.  Participate  in  necessary  consultations  with  the  key  ministries 
concerned on the partnership framework. 
(vii)  Review  the  work  of  the  international  consultants  and  provide  consolidated 
comments. 
(viii)  Organize  and  hold  the  three  consultation  workshops,  encourage  active 
participation by steering committee members, and give presentations.

reports.  
  
5.  Domestic Biomass Energy Specialist (6 person-months). The consultant will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  Together with the biomass resource specialist, and international biomass energy 
specialist, review the current status of energy use in rural areas (mainly for 
cooking, heating and electricity) to identify the contribution of BRE to farmers’ 
total energy supply. Address future trends in rural energy demand. 
(ii)  Make a matching analysis of BRE resources and rural energy demands, and 
evaluate the gap between resources and demands. Identify opportunities for 
BRE development in the selected provinces and regions. 
(iii)  Identify and recommend affordable and environmentally friendly technological 
pathways linking resources and demand in rural areas, and establish a biomass 
renewable energy development roadmap in the selected regions that can serve 
as the basis for the rural biomass national strategy and partnership framework.

(v)  Prepare related chapters or sections of TA documents and reports, and conduct

6.  Domestic Biomass Resource Specialist (6 person-months). The consultant will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  Working closely with other consultants, survey biomass resources in rural areas. 
Review  and  update  the  estimates  of  biomass  energy  resources  including

bean stalks), animal wastes and other agriculture-related biomass, for energy

(ii)  Analyze  trends  for  competing  uses  of  biomass  for  other  purposes,  such  as

(iv)  Working together with other consultants, assist in evaluating energy demands in

(v)  Participate in workshop and seminar presentations, prepare related chapters or 
sections of TA documents and reports, and conduct other related work assigned 
by the team leader/deputy team leader.  
 
7.  Domestic Investment and Financial Specialist (6 person-months). The consultant will 
do the following: 
 
(i)  Review the existing investment program and plan for rural BRE development, 
and work with the team leader to study the possibilities of integrated planning 
practices to support effective long-term management of local biomass resources. 
(ii)  Advise on measures to improve the effectiveness of financing investments in 
BRE, including domestic bonds projects. Analyze mechanisms to significantly 
reduce investor uncertainties and enable investors to recover higher incremental 
costs thorough favored BRE pricing approaches, such as the feed-in tariff pricing 
system  and  the  renewable  portfolio  standards  quota  system.  Consider  the 
Renewable  Energy  Law  and  address  consumer  financing  mechanisms  to 
enhance consumers’ ability to pay for BRE  services.

strategies for attracting external financing  (from lenders such as World Bank and 
ADB, from bilateral aid agencies, and through private sector participation, and by 
investigating the applicability of CDM and GEF), covering appropriate financial 
methods and mechanisms and the possible integration of external sources with 
domestic bonds.  
(iv)  Work with the international environmental and energy policy specialist to develop 
a partnership framework for external assistance to identify the opportunities for 
external international BRE stakeholders. Analyze how to effectively use foreign 
direct investments, including specialized funds—such as the GEF—to encourage 
further investments in renewable technologies by covering the incremental costs 
of BRE projects.
